description: Input Fields allow users to enter freeform text. Variations on this field often provide specific data entry formats such as masked data (e.g. passwords or phone numbers), date and time, and numeric data entry.
heading: Input Field

description: Action Buttons allow users to trigger actions by clicking, tapping, or pressing a corresponding key on a keyboard, such as the “Enter” key.
heading: Button

description: A “card” is a UI design pattern that groups related information in a flexible-size container visually resembling a playing card.
heading: Card

description: Tabs in Astro applications are used to divide major areas of content and to indicate work process.
heading: Tabs

description: Push Buttons are a variant of the Switch that incorporate label and action into a single user interface element. Push Buttons may provide a useful interface element where screen real-estate is at a premium.
heading: Push Button

description: Action Buttons allow users to trigger actions by clicking, tapping, or pressing a corresponding key on a keyboard, such as the “Enter” key.
heading: Data Visualization

description: A Slider allows users to choose from a range of continuous and discrete values arranged from minimum to maximum.
heading: Slider

description: When activated, Select Menus allow users to select a value from a list. Once a value is selected, the Select Menu displays the selected value.
heading: Select

description: Textareas are multi-line text inputs that allow for entering text in a larger area than a single-line text input would allow. They are typically used for multi-line input use cases like comments or feedback.
heading: Textarea

description: Component specific tokens to be used only when rebuilding components
heading: Component Tokens

description: Tokens representing Astro semantic design decisions
heading: System Tokens

description: This is the nav for the nav example
heading: Secondary Nav Example
Tables are a fundamental UX design tool for organizing and displaying data.
Directing and maintaining satellites orbiting in space requires coordinating personnel, processes, and equipment on the ground. This is the role of Ground Resource Management (GRM) systems.
